defs.docs:
This crate contains officially sanctioned contributor libraries that provide
 functionality commonly used by Rocket applications.

attributes.value: ! This crate contains officially sanctioned contributor libraries that provide
! functionality commonly used by Rocket applications.
! These libraries are always kept in-sync with the core Rocket library. They
! provide common, but not fundamental, abstractions to be used by Rocket
! Each module in this library is held behind a feature flag, with the most
! common modules exposed by default. The present feature list is below, with
! an asterisk next to the features that are enabled by default:
! * [helmet](helmet) - Fairing for Security and Privacy Headers
! The recommend way to include features from this crate via Cargo in your
! project is by adding a `[dependencies.rocket_contrib]` section to your
! `Cargo.toml` file, setting `default-features` to false, and specifying
! features manually. For example, to use the JSON module, you would add:
! This crate is expected to grow with time, bringing in outside crates to be

defs.name: json
defs.docs: Automatic JSON (de)serialization support.

attributes.value: ! See the [`Json`](crate::json::Json) type for further details.
! This module is only available when the `json` feature is enabled. Enable it

defs.name: Json
defs.docs:
The JSON type: implements [`FromData`] and [`Responder`], allowing you to
 easily consume and respond with JSON.

attributes.value: / The JSON type: implements [`FromData`] and [`Responder`], allowing you to
/ easily consume and respond with JSON.
/ If you're receiving JSON data, simply add a `data` parameter to your route
/ arguments and ensure the type of the parameter is a `Json<T>`, where `T` is
/ some type you'd like to parse from JSON. `T` must implement [`Deserialize`]
/ or from [`serde`]. The data is parsed from the HTTP request body.
/ You don't _need_ to use `format = "json"`, but it _may_ be what you want.
/ Using `format = json` means that any request that doesn't specify
/ "application/json" as its `Content-Type` header value will not be routed to
/ If you're responding with JSON data, return a `Json<T>` type, where `T`
/ implements [`Serialize`] from [`serde`]. The content type of the response is
/ The default size limit for incoming JSON data is 1MiB. Setting a limit
/ protects your application from denial of service (DoS) attacks and from
/ resource exhaustion through high memory consumption. The limit can be
/ increased by setting the `limits.json` configuration parameter. For
/ instance, to increase the JSON limit to 5MiB for all environments, you may

defs.name: Parse
defs.docs:
The client's data was received successfully but failed to parse as valid
 JSON or as the requested type. The `&str` value in `.0` is the raw data
 received from the user, while the `Error` in `.1` is the deserialization
 error from `serde`.

defs.name: Options
defs.docs: A bitset representing configurable options for the [`StaticFiles`] handler.

/   * [`Options::DotFiles`] - In addition to visible files, return dotfiles.

defs.name: None
defs.docs:
`Options` representing the empty set. No dotfiles or index pages are
 rendered. This is different than [`Options::default()`](#impl-Default),
 which enables `Index`.

attributes.value: / `Options` representing the empty set. No dotfiles or index pages are

defs.name: Index
defs.docs:
`Options` enabling responding to requests for a directory with the
 `index.html` file in that directory, if it exists. When this is enabled,
 the [`StaticFiles`] handler will respond to requests for a directory
 `/foo` with the file `${root}/foo/index.html` if it exists. This is
 enabled by default.

attributes.value: / `Options` enabling responding to requests for a directory with the
/ `index.html` file in that directory, if it exists. When this is enabled,
/ the [`StaticFiles`] handler will respond to requests for a directory
/ `/foo` with the file `${root}/foo/index.html` if it exists. This is

defs.name: DotFiles
defs.docs:
`Options` enabling returning dot files. When this is enabled, the
 [`StaticFiles`] handler will respond to requests for files or
 directories beginning with `.`. This is _not_ enabled by default.

attributes.value: / `Options` enabling returning dot files. When this is enabled, the
/ [`StaticFiles`] handler will respond to requests for files or
/ directories beginning with `.`. This is _not_ enabled by default.

defs.name: NormalizeDirs
defs.docs:
`Options` that normalizes directory requests by redirecting requests to
 directory paths without a trailing slash to ones with a trailing slash.

attributes.value: / `Options` that normalizes directory requests by redirecting requests to
/ directory paths without a trailing slash to ones with a trailing slash.
/ When enabled, the [`StaticFiles`] handler will respond to requests for a
/ directory without a trailing `/` with a permanent redirect (308) to the
/ same path with a trailing `/`. This ensures relative URLs within any
/ document served for that directory will be interpreted relative to that
/ directory, rather than its parent. This is _not_ enabled by default.

defs.name: contains
defs.docs:
Returns `true` if `self` is a superset of `other`. In other words,
 returns `true` if all of the options in `other` are also in `self`.

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if `self` is a superset of `other`. In other words,
/ returns `true` if all of the options in `other` are also in `self`.

defs.name: StaticFiles
defs.docs: Custom handler for serving static files.

attributes.value: / Custom handler for serving static files.
/ This handler makes it simple to serve static files from a directory on the
/ local file system. To use it, construct a `StaticFiles` using either
/ handler at a desired path. When mounted, the handler will generate route(s)
/ that serve the desired static files.
/ The handler's functionality can be customized by passing an [`Options`] to
/ [`StaticFiles::new()`]. Additionally, the rank of generate routes, which
/ defaults to `10`, can be set via the [`StaticFiles::rank()`] builder method.
/ To serve files from the `/static` directory at the `/public` path, allowing
/ `index.html` files to be used to respond to requests for a directory (the
/ default), you might write the following:
/ With this set-up, requests for files at `/public/<path..>` will be handled
/ by returning the contents of `/static/<path..>`. Requests for _directories_
/ at `/public/<directory>` will be handled by returning the contents of
/ If your static files are stored relative to your crate and your project is
/ managed by Cargo, you should either use a relative path and ensure that your
/ server is started in the crate's root directory or use the
/ `CARGO_MANIFEST_DIR` to create an absolute path relative to your crate root.
/ For example, to serve files in the `static` subdirectory of your crate at

defs.name: from
defs.docs:
Constructs a new `StaticFiles` that serves files from the file system
 `path`. By default, [`Options::Index`] is set, and the generated routes
 have a rank of `10`. To serve static files with other options, use
 [`StaticFiles::new()`]. To choose a different rank for generated routes,
 use [`StaticFiles::rank()`].

attributes.value: / Constructs a new `StaticFiles` that serves files from the file system
/ `path`. By default, [`Options::Index`] is set, and the generated routes
/ have a rank of `10`. To serve static files with other options, use
/ [`StaticFiles::new()`]. To choose a different rank for generated routes,
/ Serve the static files in the `/www/public` local directory on path
/ Exactly as before, but set the rank for generated routes to `30`.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Constructs a new `StaticFiles` that serves files from the file system
 `path` with `options` enabled. By default, the handler's routes have a
 rank of `10`. To choose a different rank, use [`StaticFiles::rank()`].

attributes.value: / Constructs a new `StaticFiles` that serves files from the file system
/ `path` with `options` enabled. By default, the handler's routes have a
/ rank of `10`. To choose a different rank, use [`StaticFiles::rank()`].
/ Serve the static files in the `/www/public` local directory on path
/ `/static` without serving index files or dot files. Additionally, serve
/ the same files on `/pub` with a route rank of -1 while also serving

defs.name: rank
defs.docs: Sets the rank for generated routes to `rank`.

attributes.value: / Sets the rank for generated routes to `rank`.
/ // A `StaticFiles` created with `from()` with routes of rank `3`.
/ // A `StaticFiles` created with `new()` with routes of rank `-15`.

defs.name: templates
defs.docs: Dynamic template engine support for handlebars and tera.

attributes.value: ! Dynamic template engine support for handlebars and tera.
! The general outline for using templates in Rocket is:
!   0. Enable the `rocket_contrib` feature corresponding to your templating
!   1. Write your template files in Handlebars (extension: `.hbs`) or tera
!   3. Return a [`Template`] using [`Template::render()`], supplying the name
!      of the template file minus the last two extensions, from a handler.
! Template names passed in to [`Template::render()`] must correspond to a
! previously discovered template in the configured template directory. The
! template directory is configured via the `template_dir` configuration
! parameter and defaults to `templates/`. The path set in `template_dir` is
! relative to the Rocket configuration file. See the [configuration
! The corresponding templating engine used for a given template is based on a
! template's extension. At present, this library supports the following
! Any file that ends with one of these extension will be discovered and
! rendered with the corresponding templating engine. The _name_ of the
! template will be the path to the template file relative to `template_dir`
! minus at most two extensions. The following table illustrates this mapping:
! The recommended naming scheme is to use two extensions: one for the file
! type, and one for the template extension. This means that template
! Template discovery is actualized by the template fairing, which itself is
! created via [`Template::fairing()`] or [`Template::custom()`], the latter of
! which allows for customizations to the templating engine. In order for _any_
! templates to be rendered, the template fairing _must_ be
! [attached](rocket::Rocket::attach()) to the running Rocket instance. Failure
! to do so will result in a run-time error.
! Templates are rendered with the `render` method. The method takes in the
! name of a template and a context to render the template with. The context
! can be any type that implements [`Serialize`] from [`serde`] and would
! In debug mode (without the `--release` flag passed to `cargo`), templates
! will be automatically reloaded from disk if any changes have been made to
! the templates directory since the previous request. In release builds,
! template reloading is disabled to improve performance and cannot be enabled.

defs.name: Engines
defs.docs: A structure exposing access to templating engines.

attributes.value: / A structure exposing access to templating engines.
/ Calling methods on the exposed template engine types may require importing
/ types from the respective templating engine library. These types should be
/ imported from the reexported crate at the root of `rocket_contrib` to avoid
/ version mismatches. For instance, when registering a Tera filter, the
/ [`tera::Value`] and [`tera::Result`] types are required. Import them from
/ fn my_filter(value: Value, _: HashMap<String, Value>) -> tera::Result<Value> {

defs.name: handlebars
defs.docs:
The Handlebars templating engine. This field is only available when the
 `handlebars_templates` feature is enabled. When calling methods on the
 `Tera` instance, ensure you use types imported from
 `rocket_contrib::templates::handlebars` to avoid version mismatches.

attributes.value: / The Handlebars templating engine. This field is only available when the
/ `handlebars_templates` feature is enabled. When calling methods on the
/ `Tera` instance, ensure you use types imported from

defs.name: Template
defs.docs: Responder that renders a dynamic template.

attributes.value: / Responder that renders a dynamic template.
/ To use, add the `handlebars_templates` feature, the `tera_templates`
/ feature, or both, to the `rocket_contrib` dependencies section of your
/ Then, ensure that the template [`Fairing`] is attached to your Rocket
/ The `Template` type implements Rocket's [`Responder`] trait, so it can be
/ returned from a request handler directly:
/ You may use the [`Template::custom()`] method to construct a fairing with
/ customized templating engines. Among other things, this method allows you to
/ register template helpers and register templates from strings.

defs.name: fairing
defs.docs: Returns a fairing that initializes and maintains templating state.

attributes.value: / Returns a fairing that initializes and maintains templating state.
/ This fairing, or the one returned by [`Template::custom()`], _must_ be
/ attached to any `Rocket` instance that wishes to render templates.
/ Failure to attach this fairing will result in a "Uninitialized template
/ context: missing fairing." error message when a template is attempted to
/ If you wish to customize the internal templating engines, use
/ To attach this fairing, simple call `attach` on the application's

defs.name: custom
defs.docs: Returns a fairing that initializes and maintains templating state.

attributes.value: / Returns a fairing that initializes and maintains templating state.
/ Unlike [`Template::fairing()`], this method allows you to configure
/ templating engines via the parameter `f`. Note that only the enabled
/ templating engines will be accessible from the `Engines` type.

defs.name: render
defs.docs:
Render the template named `name` with the context `context`. The
 `context` can be of any type that implements `Serialize`. This is
 typically a `HashMap` or a custom `struct`.

attributes.value: / Render the template named `name` with the context `context`. The
/ `context` can be of any type that implements `Serialize`. This is
/ // Create a `context`. Here, just an empty `HashMap`.

defs.name: show
defs.docs:
Render the template named `name` with the context `context` into a
 `String`. This method should **not** be used in any running Rocket
 application. This method should only be used during testing to validate
 `Template` responses. For other uses, use [`render()`](#method.render)
 instead.

/ `String`. This method should **not** be used in any running Rocket
/ application. This method should only be used during testing to validate
/ The `context` can be of any type that implements `Serialize`. This is
/ Returns `Some` if the template could be rendered. Otherwise, returns
/ `None`. If rendering fails, error output is printed to the console.
/ `None` is also returned if a `Template` fairing has not been attached.
